page.title: Diagnostic, Formative and Summative Assessment
page.contents:
Diagnostic, Formative and Summative Assessment

Now that you have considered some of your own and others’ experiences with assessment, taken a self-assessment to gauge your knowledge level, and chosen a course goal, it’s time to cover some fundamental information about the three types of assessment and the purposes of each.  This week, we’ll focus on diagnostic, formative and summative assessment, what each is best suited for, and who uses which type. 

The Lesson Objectives for Topic 2 are to:

  • understand diagnostic, formative and summative assessment;
  • describe the different uses for each assessment;
  • identify the stakeholders in your program and their interests;
  • identify which assessments will yield the most useful information for each stakeholder.
  • become familiar with ways to search LINCS for adult education resources.

page.title: A Primer: Diagnostic, Formative and Summative Assessment
page.contents:
To begin, please read the article below, which outlines each of the types of assessment—diagnostic, formative, and summative—and discusses their specific uses. While each of these types serves different purposes and audiences, all three are important to combine if a clear snapshot of a student’s skills and abilities are to be measured. Diagnostic assessment reveals a student’s initial strengths and needs (where to start); formative assessment provides an on-going look at a student’s progress (how to proceed); and summative assessment provides an evaluation or culmination of a student’s effort and performance once a program of study has completed (what to conclude).

A Primer: Diagnostic, Formative, & Summative Assessment (pdf format)
Resource from the LINCS Professional Development Resource Collection

Questions for Discussion:

Now we ask you to consider the following questions for discussion with your peers:

  • What assessments do you use in your program and for what purpose(s)?
  • Do you feel these assessments meet student’s needs? How could this be improved?
